The US may take action against France, Germany, and the UK for their attempts to appease Iran.
EU companies trading with Iran are bolstering one of the most evil regimes in the world.
0d8e6eb785b0848d790a59b0ece5d7bb:
Iranian ambassador to Britain Hamid Baeedinejad criticized those mocking the European Union's special financial mechanism for trade with Iran, INSTEX.
INSTEX is a financial institution and not a part of the European Commission, so it is not necessary for all member states of the European Union to join it.
Britain, France and Germany issued a joint statement on the creation of INSTEX that will allow trade between the EU and Iran without relying on direct financial transactions.
INSTEX will support legitimate European trade with Iran, focusing initially on the sectors most essential to the Iranian population.
INSTEX has been registered in France and will be run by German banker and former Commerzbank manager Per Fischer.
The European Union has vowed to counter Trump’s renewed sanctions on Iran, including by means of a new law to shield European companies from punitive measures.
The US president pulled his country out of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) on May 8.
Trump signed an executive order re-imposing many sanctions on Iran on August 6.
The second batch of US sanctions against Iran took effect on November 4.
424522e21ac8d478fabf44898e99459e:
EU has tried to salvage the 2015 nuclear deal with Iran after the US President’s departure from the deal.
Iran has tested a new ballistic missile, which is in direct violation of the Iranian regime’s obligation to adhere to UN Resolution 2231.
Iran has been involved in a series of terrorist activities on European soil since 2015.
The EU has imposed the first round of sanctions on Iran since the 2015 Iran deal.
The sanctions target a section of the Iranian Ministry of Intelligence and Security (MOIS) and two individuals, including Assadollah Assadi, who masterminded a terrorist plot in Paris.
The EU has expelled Iranian diplomats in response to the failed terrorist plot in Paris and the assassinations of two Iranian dissidents in the Netherlands.
The EU has delivered a strong message to Iran that it will no longer tolerate Iranian regime’s missile tests and assassination plots on its soil.
bf46f1e11b6b7725717f626450ee193e:
Iran’s Ambassador in London Hamid Baeidinejad said that the EU has no right to set conditions for implementing the Instrument in Support of Trade Exchanges (INSTEX).
The E3 joint statement does not mention that joining FATF bills is a condition for Iran to use INSTEX; rather it is said it is an expectation from Iran.
The E3 expect Iran to swiftly implement all elements of its FATF action plan.
The E3 underline their commitment to pursue further development of INSTEX with interested European countries.
0094b88edfbedeb8257f0ec795de513d:
The European Union (EU) has condemned Iran's missile program and "unacceptable behavior" in Europe and the Middle East.
Iran has rejected the EU's concerns as "baseless" and "non-constructive."
The EU has urged Iran to stop ballistic missile tests and assassination attempts on Iranian dissidents in Europe.
The EU is concerned about Iran's military involvement in Syria.
The EU supports the 2015 nuclear deal with Iran.
The US has pressured European allies to cut ties with Iran.
The EU has accused Iran of involvement in assassination attempts in France, Denmark and the Netherlands.
The EU has sanctioned Iran's Ministry for Intelligence and Security for its alleged involvement in the attacks.
The EU has tried to circumvent US sanctions on Iran by creating INSTEX, a transactions channel for European businesses.
1a8ee777ebc8f3df8abdd2a8ca95d262:
Iran’s top judge Sadeq Amoli-Larijani said that Tehran would never accept the “humiliating conditions” set by the European Union for non-dollar trade intended to evade U.S. sanctions.
France, Germany and Britain have opened a new channel for non-dollar trade with Iran to get around the sanctions.
Iran will never accept the conditions of joining the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) and negotiations on its missile program.
The European statement said they expected Iran to swiftly implement all elements of its FATF action plan.
Iran has threatened to pull out of the nuclear deal unless the European powers enable it to receive economic benefits.
The EU this month imposed its first sanctions on Iran since the nuclear pact, in response to assassination plots on European soil.
cae408cd662ff9dca37c791fa944975f:
Iran’s judiciary chief, Ayatollah Sadeq Amoli Larijani, criticized the new payment system set up by France, Germany, and the UK to allow “legitimate trade” with Iran, saying it has limited capacity and humiliating conditions.
The new payment channel named the Instrument in Support of Trade Exchanges (INSTEX) was launched by France, Germany, and the UK in the wake of US sanctions.
European countries have set two “strange conditions” for the mechanism: Iran should join the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) and enter negotiations on its missile program.
Iran will not accept these humiliating conditions and will not accede to any demand at the expense of opening a small waterway such as INSTEX, said Larijani.
Some experts said the mechanism was useless and won’t change anything for European companies as they cannot feel confident that they could do business with Iran without being subject to US sanctions.
af3d71e5f53a496b2e091cd023616eab:
The EU is committed to preserving the 2015 Iran nuclear deal and is reportedly on the verge of implementing a special payment mechanism (INSTEX) to evade US sanctions.
The US has imposed more sanctions on Iran-backed militias in Syria and a commercial airline accused of smuggling for the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps.
The US has warned European partners against implementing INSTEX, threatening penalties.
European supporters of INSTEX have not been deterred by US warnings.
The UK and France have called for a meeting over Iran's ballistic missile activities, and the EU has imposed sanctions on the Iranian intelligence service.
European officials acknowledge that INSTEX's initial impact may be minor and that it will initially deal with transactions already permitted under US sanctions.
American officials are concerned about INSTEX challenging the US-linked SWIFT banking system.
Iranian officials have raised their expectations for European countermeasures to US pressure.
Many prominent Iranian politicians are urging the cancellation of the nuclear deal.
Iran's judiciary head has rejected preconditions set by European signatories of the nuclear deal, including joining the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) and negotiating on its missile program.
The EU has issued a joint statement expressing concerns about Iran's ballistic missile program.
Europe is eager to show the US that it can be tough on Iran, but this does not override its efforts to preserve the nuclear deal.
Iran has tested a new cruise missile capable of flying 800 miles, boasting of its "long arm."
The Long War Journal criticizes European complacency in addressing Iran's cruise missile capabilities.
52bafd6f3be0a938544ba90226d9c1e3:
Germany, France and the UK have set up a payment channel with Iran called INSTEX to circumvent US sanctions.
The US Department of Treasury imposed primary and secondary sanctions against the Iranian government after US President Donald Trump pulled out of the nuclear agreement last year.
The EU did not take the US sanctions seriously until the US began holding those who were allegedly breaching the sanctions accountable.
The EU is attempting to depict INSTEX as a mechanism that is built to save the nuclear deal.
The Iranian leaders, as well as the conservative and moderate news outlets, have been playing the good cop, bad cop strategy.
The EU is unlikely to succeed in continuing to trade with the Iranian regime through its new mechanism because it will not help Tehran to gain more revenues, most European firms have already abandoned their plans to invest in Iran, and European companies will not want to risk their business with the US or access to US financial systems by dealing with Iran.
a4b88ec1be0c706edce1a2ac5c606056:
France, Germany, and Britain have launched INSTEX, a financial mechanism to facilitate trade with Iran despite US sanctions.
INSTEX is limited to trading food and medicine, which are not subject to US secondary sanctions.
Europe is urging Iran to join the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) as a condition for activating INSTEX.
Iranian lawmaker Mohammad Javad Koulivand criticizes INSTEX as a "mere PR show" and a tool to pressure Iran into meeting European demands.
Ali Motahari, a member of the Iranian Parliament, welcomes INSTEX but warns against linking it to FATF membership.
MP Seyyed Amir-Hossein Ghazizadeh Hashemi believes INSTEX is "only a piece of paper" and will not benefit Iran.
Yaghoub Shiviari expresses concerns that INSTEX could become a supplement to US sanctions and a tool to extract concessions from Iran.
Shiviari warns that INSTEX could facilitate US monitoring of Iran's oil sales and trade partners.
c4fc6e591af23036b6840d0c79c0d9f9:
EU continues to pursue appeasement policies toward Iran, including charting paths to trade with the regime and skirt the US’ sanctions.
EU believes that sanctions relief will curtail or make Iran abandon its nuclear ambitions, but Iran has not moved in that direction.
Iran is exploring new uranium enrichment programs and the production of centrifuges, and is on the threshold of modernizing its mechanism to produce highly enriched uranium.
Iran views the JCPOA as a temporary and transitory deal, while the EU believes it will fundamentally alter Iran’s nuclear ambitions.
Iran has not substantially scaled back its nuclear activities, including research and development, after almost four years of the JCPOA’s sanctions relief and increased trade.
Iran has been pursuing a “clandestine” path to obtaining nuclear technology and equipment from German companies.
Iran’s “nerve center,” which is reportedly responsible for designing a nuclear bomb, has been continuing its work.
Appeasement of Iran is counterproductive because it sends a message to the Iranian leaders that continuing their nuclear path will give them more leverage and advantage over the international community.
69f07d3241db367cddc3b01da5f18409:
Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman Bahram Qasemi criticized the slow progress of implementing INSTEX between Iran and Europe.
INSTEX is a payment channel set up by Germany, France and the UK to help continue trade with Tehran and circumvent the US sanctions.
The US is not happy with improving Iran-Europe relations and is continuing its pressures and acts of sabotage against Tehran.
An expert meeting will be held within days to review the INSTEX, attended by European officials and the Iranian foreign ministry and economic apparatus.
Iran has made it clear to Europe that the patience of the Iranian nation and government "is not limitless" so the Europeans should implement it very fast.
Europe's financial mechanism for trade with Iran and the four Financial Action Task Force's (FATF) bills in the country are not interrelated.
Iran is not a country which would yield to terms and conditions.
b745ab89987e38a496406b3e64166884:
The Palestinian Authority (PA) transferred over $135 million to imprisoned terrorists in 2018.
More than $62 million was sent to terrorists while they were in jail, while almost $48 million was paid to released prisoners.
Roughly $26 million was used to pay other terrorist-related salaries and additional benefits.
Payments are a function of the severity of the attack and prison sentence.
The more brutal the attack or murder, the more money a Palestinian prisoner receives.
Prisoners with previous arrests receive more money as well.
Israel’s Knesset passed legislation last July to impose structured sanctions targeting the PA for its financial incentives to murder program.
Senior Palestinian officials, including PA President Mahmoud Abbas, issued defiant assurances that they would not end the payments.
Roughly half of the foreign aid that the PA receives is allocated for payments to terrorist inmates and the “families of martyrs.”
c207659fff5c61616ab896527d330fc3:
The Diplomatic-Security Cabinet is expected to approve a major cut to the tax revenues that Israel collects on behalf of the Palestinian Authority (P.A.).
The amount the P.A. pays to terrorists and their families will be deducted from the money Israel hands over to the P.A.
The reduction will be enacted under a law passed this past summer by Knesset members Elazar Stern (Yesh Atid) and Avi Dichter (Likud).
The Defense Ministry has been assiduously collecting figures to determine the exact amount that the P.A. pays out in “terror salaries.”
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has said in closed-door talks that the deduction will go ahead.
Dichter said in response to recent reports on the amount of the P.A. terror salaries that “every shekel the Palestinian Authority pays to terrorists will be deducted [from the tax funds.] That is how we create deterrence against terrorism.”
Israel Hayom recently reported that in 2018, the P.A. paid out 502 million shekels ($138 million) to living terrorists.
A probe by the Palestinian Media Watch group showed that at least 230 million shekels ($63 million) had been paid to terrorists currently in prison.
dc4386370d7af07de8e6a7ba4081ec2b:
The Palestinian Authority (PA) government condemned Israel's decision to cut off financial aid for Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails.
The PA government called the Israeli move "an act of piracy and a breach of the agreements" between the PA and Israel.
The PA government accused the Israeli government of coordinating with the U.S. administration "to pressure Palestinians and force the Palestinian leadership to accept the century deal."
The PA government urged the U.S. administration to "stop its incitement and pressure policy."
The Israeli Knesset (parliament) passed a new bill last July, allowing Israeli authorities to deduct millions of dollars from the Palestinian tax revenues it collects on behalf of the PA.
37158815857255b11d9d7b1b4eb37dfc:
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced that he will begin cutting funds to the Palestinian Authority (PA) over its payments to terrorists and their families within a week.
The decision comes amid pressure on Netanyahu to act after the arrest of a Palestinian man, Arafat Irfayia, 29, on Friday following the murder of 19-year-old Ori Ansbacher in a southern Jerusalem wood a day earlier.
The Knesset passed a law in July slashing Palestinian tax funds Israel transfers to the PA by the amount Ramallah pays to convicted terrorists and the families of Palestinians killed while carrying out attacks.
The government has refused to implement the power given to it by the law to freeze the fund transfers, but politicians have faced public pressure to crack down on the PA’s payments.
The PA allocated NIS 691 million ($183 million) for the families of so-called “martyrs” and wounded persons in its 2018 budget.
Last March, US President Donald Trump signed into law legislation that requires the American government to cut some aid to the Palestinians until they end payments to terrorists and slain attackers.
Right-wing politicians over the weekend called for the instituting of a death penalty for terrorists in Israeli law.
c979f53824bfe4d86f80a0e50b442ac5:
The Israeli government will approve a law to confiscate funds allocated by the Palestinian Authority (PA) to Palestinians it claims are involved in attacks against Israeli targets.
Israel collects tariffs and duties on behalf of the Ramallah-based PA under 1994 Oslo Accords.
The PA threatened not to accept the money if Israel deducts any funds.
The Knesset (Israel's parliament) passed legislation requiring the Defence Ministry to inform the security cabinet of how much the PA pays in "welfare" payments to Palestinians involved in attacks against Israeli targets.
d12e61544824be921a8e47c6bfc07944:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has promised to implement a plan to deduct certain amounts from the tax that Israel collects on behalf of the Palestinian Authority (PA).
The deduction will be relative to the amounts the PA pays to the Palestinians languishing in Israeli jails or the families of those killed by the regime's military.
The Palestinian Civil Affairs Minister Hussein al-Sheikh said that the PA would take none of the money if Israel withheld even "a penny."
The Tel Aviv regime collects around 127 million dollars a month in duties levied on goods destined for Palestinian markets that transit through Israeli "customs" and then transfers it to the PA.
In early July last year, Israel's parliament passed a bill to withhold hundreds of millions of dollars in funds from the Palestinians over welfare payments given to prisoners and their families.
2cc4dd4da2e2c424fbcf4e21b85ba912: Finance Minister Moshe Kahlon said that the law meant to deduct terrorists' salaries from the Palestinian Authority’s funds is “correct, just and moral.”
The Ministry of Finance is prepared to make the cutbacks in accordance with the law.
01aa04d4eccfed7e5788662f53e46371:
The Palestinian Authority (PA) paid out NIS 230 million to 13,656 families of "martyrs" (terrorists killed carrying out attacks against Israel) in 2018.
The figures are based on data from leftist groups, the PA and the Shin Bet, and were prepared by the Palestinian Media Watch (PMW) organization.
The PA also paid out approximately NIS 500 million in 2018 to families of terrorists in Israeli prisons, or as pensions to terrorists who have been released from prison.
Overall, the PA pays out NIS 732 million (over $200 million) to terrorists and their families, dead or alive.
Prime Minister Binyamin Netanyahu said that by the end of the week a mechanism should be in place to deduct money transferred to the PA in the amount of payouts to terrorists, as required by Knesset legislation passed last July that came into effect on January 1st.
PMW head Itamar Marcus said that "the report shows that over 13,000 families of ‘martyr’ terrorists are getting paid by the PA, in addition to some 6,000 terrorists who are getting a salary from the PA. This is a clear measure of how the PA is supporting terror, with all of the consequences that should follow from that."
2245fb5036923772e61c05378e652354:
5,043 Palestinians from the Gaza Strip did not receive their regular monthly salaries or government allowances from the Palestinian Authority at the beginning of February.
The withholding of the payments came on direct instructions from Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas’ office to the Palestinian Authority’s Finance and Planning Ministry.
The Gazans affected by the withholding of the payments are affiliated with either Islamic Jihad, Hamas or with supporters of Mohammed Dahlan, a rival of Abbas in the Palestinian president’s Fatah movement.
900 of the more than 5,000 people affected are recipients of prison allowances from the Palestinian Authority, and 133 of them are currently in Israeli prisons.
1,700 of the recipients affected are families receiving allowances because they have children who were killed or wounded by the Israeli army.
The withholding of the funds is being interpreted as one more economic sanction on Abbas’ part against the Gaza Strip and the Hamas movement that governs it.
Over the past two or three years, the Finance Ministry in Ramallah has gradually cut public sector salary payments in the Gaza Strip on Abbas’ orders.
About 30,000 public sector employees have either been forced to take early retirement or have had their pension payments reduced.
The wages of about 40,000 salaried employees have been reduced by 30 to 50 percent.
37f62fda6baf802118cea8296ac42e07:
Israel has decided to cut half a billion shekels in funds over its payments to security prisoners and their families.
The security cabinet approved the implementation of a law to cut NIS 502,697,000 ($138 million) from the PA, over its payments to terrorists and their families.
The move has faced opposition from the security establishment, who worry it could destabilize the situation in the West Bank.
Israel collects around $127 million a month in customs duties levied on goods destined for Palestinian markets that transit through Israeli ports, and then transfers the money to the PA.
The $138 million will likely be deducted incrementally over a 12-month period.
The law withholding the tax revenues, passed by the Knesset last year, is opposed by Israeli security officials who say further cuts to the PA budget could hurt security cooperation and destabilize the West Bank.
Netanyahu, who is seeking reelection this April, has come under increasing pressure to act in the wake of the brutal murder of an Israeli teen in a terrorist attack earlier this month.
674b19ea35b14d965de7b8f43314b05e:
Israel's security cabinet has decided to implement a law deducting tax revenues otherwise sent to the Palestinian Authority over its payments to terrorists and their families.
Senior Palestinian officials criticize the decision as a form of collective punishment that could jeopardize the Palestinian economy and undermine the PA's ability to pay its salaries on time.
Senior Palestine Liberation Organization official Ahmed Majdalani accuses Israel and the US of an attempt at blackmail and seeking to destroy the national authority.
PA officials tell Channel 13 that PA President Mahmoud Abbas may refuse to accept all of the tax revenue to protest the Israeli move.
The officials say the move is likely to damage Israeli-Palestinian security cooperation.
4327fc57fd60dbe2e43c72f305cd4749:
The Palestinian Authority (PA) is furious about the Israeli Cabinet's decision to withhold about NIS 500 million in tax transfers to the PA to match the amount it pays terrorists.
The PA's total outlay for terrorists and their families is about NIS 1.2 billion ($329 billion) a year, which is higher than the amount Israel is withholding.
The PA will not stop its payments to terrorists, and the decision will have implications on many levels.
The decision came on the same day the Cabinet approved a mechanism to deduct money transferred to the PA in the amount of payouts to terrorists, as required by Knesset legislation passed last July that came into effect on January 1st.
PMW head Itamar Marcus said that his organization's report shows that over 13,000 families of 'martyr' terrorists are getting paid by the PA, in addition to some 6,000 terrorists who are getting a salary from the PA.
129f0d9ee212093d8e65a76696cec26b:
Israel will cut around five percent of the tax handovers to the Palestinian Authority over its financial support for jailed Palestinian militants.
Israel has at times withheld money from the Palestinian Authority as a measure of protest or pressure.
Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas has held to paying stipends to the families of Palestinians jailed as security offenders or killed by Israel.
Israel and the United States say the policy fans Palestinian violence.
Abbas describes the slain and jailed Palestinians as “heroes” of a national struggle.
The Israeli security cabinet said the same amount of money that Abbas’ administration reported paying in prisoner stipends in 2018 would be “frozen” from within the taxes collected for the Palestinian Authority.
The Palestinians condemned the Israeli decision as “piracy”.
The United States passed legislation last year to sharply reduce aid to the Palestinian Authority unless it stopped the stipends.
The Palestinians last month declined some $60 million in US annual funding for their security forces.
The Trump administration has further slashed hundreds of millions of dollars to humanitarian organizations and UN agencies, which aid the Palestinians.
Some security experts voiced concern that the fiscal blows could destabilize the Palestinian Authority.
555ca62582bd26cad9514bb216c14d35:
Palestinian Minister of National Economy Abeer Odeh denounced Israel's deduction and expropriation of Palestinian tax revenue as illegal piracy.
Israel's actions are aimed at causing further deterioration in the improvised economy of the Palestinian people.
Minister Odeh called on the international community to act and ensure an end to Israel's serious and escalating violations of international laws and regulations.
Minister Odeh said that Israel, with the direct complicity and support of the United States, is ongoing with its illegal racist policies against the entire Palestinian population.
The Palestinian government is weighing all available options to counter this illegal Israeli measure.
6b39a2f2d55e964203f2ab4b95209563:
Israel's Security Cabinet implemented a law freezing Palestinian Authority funds, deducting NIS 502,697,000 (US $138,000,000) from the funds designated for transfer to the Palestinian Authority.
The funds were frozen because in 2018, the Palestinian Authority transferred the same amount to terrorists imprisoned in Israel and their families and to released prisoners.
Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu came under increasing pressure to implement the tax freeze following 19-year-old Ori Ansbacher’s brutal rape and murder earlier in the month.
Palestinian Prime Minister Rami Hamdallah said the move amounted to a “theft of Palestinian public money” and showed “Israel’s enactment of racist laws in support of the occupation” which “undermined the two-state solution.”
A PA official warned that the freeze “could jeopardize the Palestinian economy and undermine the PA’s ability to pay its salaries on time.”
Israel views the Palestinian payments as incitement to murder or pay-to-slay, while the Palestinian Authority counter claims that the payments are a source of welfare for families who have lost their main breadwinner.
The freeze comes as the Palestinians face major budget cuts made last year after the United States slashed funding for the UN’s Palestinian refugee program UNRWA and for development programs in the Palestinian territories.
dd51702b960458f0d850ce280a42b6b3:
Israel's Security Cabinet approved the implementation of a law to deduct funds from tax revenue withheld from the Palestinian Authority (P.A.) over its payments to terrorists and their families.
The move would deduct funds equal to the amount the P.A. spent to support terrorists and their families in 2018, which is $138 million.
The Israeli decision did not include deducting funds equal to the amount the P.A. spends on so-called “martyrs.”
The decision by the Security Cabinet comes as Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had come under increasing pressure to implement the law following the brutal murder of Israeli teen Ori Ansbacher by a Palestinian terrorist earlier this month.
The decision does not include deductions for Palestinian martyr payments, which is estimated to be over $63 million.
Netanyahu instructed security officials to step up checks on additional Palestinian Authority payments linked to terrorism, including those to terrorists and their families.
ad2a82663c9a6aff144d136b6625e51d:
Israel will cut around 5 per cent of the tax handovers to the Palestinian Authority over its financial support for jailed Palestinians.
Israel has at times withheld money as a measure of protest or pressure.
Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas has held to paying stipends to the families of Palestinians jailed as security offenders or killed by Israel.
Israel and the United States say the policy fans Palestinian violence.
Abbas describes the slain and jailed Palestinians as "heroes" of a national struggle.
The Israeli Cabinet said the same amount of $138 million would be "frozen" from within the taxes collected for the Palestinian Authority.
The Palestinians condemned the Israeli decision as "piracy".
The United States passed legislation last year to sharply reduce aid to the Palestinian Authority unless it stopped the stipends.
The Palestinians last month declined some $60 million in US annual funding for their security forces.
The Trump administration has further slashed hundreds of millions of dollars to humanitarian organisations and UN agencies which aid the Palestinians.
ab3f844bc7fc6046ac7cbdfe1379c7f0:
The security cabinet decided to freeze the transfer of 500 million shekels ($138 million) of Palestinian Authority taxes as a sanction for its support of security prisoners.
The law allowing the funds to be frozen was passed in July, but no politician seemed in any hurry to implement it.
The murder of Ori Ansbacher in Jerusalem earlier this month led to renewed discussion of the assistance the PA gives to terrorists and their families.
The funds freeze relates only to the imprisoned terrorists, not to the annual assistance that the PA gives to the families of Palestinians who were killed in confrontations with Israel.
The Israeli decision to stop the tax transfers puts more pressure on the PA leaders than the steps the American administration has taken to reduce the financial aid to the territories.
The PA is threatening to completely halt the cooperation between it and Israel.
Hamas isn’t prepared to make do with what it has achieved in recent months and seems to believe that Netanyahu is more vulnerable to blackmail now.
The nighttime demonstrations in the Gaza Strip have resumed and are now taking place almost daily.
56abcba3b6e0f2a04ce2757f07f8217c:
Kerem Shalom crossing, Gaza's most important entry point for commercial goods, is operating normally on Monday.
The Gazan side of Kerem Shalom crossing is run by officials unaffiliated with the Palestinian Authority (PA), including Hamas.
The PA officials walked out of the Kerem Shalom crossing on Sunday and have yet to return.
Hamas claims the PA's move was part of the PA's efforts to punish Hamas and was intended to shutter the vital crossing.
PA officials complain that their clerks were “expelled” by Hamas officials who took over the administration of the crossing.
The PA's reasons for removing its clerks from Kerem Shalom are not yet fully clear.
One theory argues that the move follows the Israeli cabinet's decision on Sunday to implement a July 2018 law cutting tax fund transfers to the PA by the amount spent by the PA on salaries and stipends for convicted Palestinian attackers and their families, including terrorists.
The PA has warned that it could decide to simply refuse to receive all money from Israel, including taxes collected by Israel from Palestinians under PA rule.
Hamas turned its ire on Israel, renewing nightly protests and sabotage operations led by its “night units” along the Israel-Gaza border.
An explosive device was tossed at IDF troops, leaving one soldier moderately wounded, while 19 Palestinians were injured in IDF return fire.
8db4efcb06bf08ed10efd3c6cd77a78f:
Israel has "sole control" over the external borders and collection of import taxes and VAT of the Palestinian Authority.
Israel has intermittently frozen tax transfers to the Palestinian Authority since the Oslo accords were signed 25 years ago.
The freezing of tax fund transfers will be a "dangerous contribution to the deterioration of humanitarian and economic conditions" in the Palestinian Authority.
Israel treats the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip as a single economic unit, thus generating immense revenue from near-monopoly access to Palestinian markets.
Sanctioning Palestinian tax revenue "is tantamount to collective punishment prohibited under international law."
The tax revenue freeze is the latest financial blow to Palestinians living in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and in refugee camps in Syria, Jordan and Lebanon.
The United Nations agency for Palestine refugees has been disqualified from receiving US funding "unless it agrees to pay court judgments of sometimes up to hundreds of millions of dollars on behalf of American victims of Palestinian attacks."
President Donald Trump has admitted to using US funding as leverage to advance his administration's Israeli-Palestinian "peace deal."
Israeli media have reported that Trump's plan will include the annexation of Israel's major settlement blocs in the West Bank.
The Israeli government plans to significantly expand settlements in the West Bank, including outposts built without formal authorization.
All Israeli settlements in the West Bank, including East Jerusalem, violate international law, which prohibits an occupying power from transferring its civilian population to the territory it occupies.
114cc9d11979d4fe4a6a6172e039a549:
Israel's security cabinet decided to withhold $138 million in tax transfers to the Palestinian Authority (PA) over its payments to prisoners jailed for attacks on Israelis.
Israel alleges the payments encourage further violence, while the PA says they are a form of welfare to the families who have lost their main breadwinner.
The move to withhold the money comes in response to an Israeli law passed last year allowing it to do so.
Israel collects around $127 million a month in customs duties levied on goods destined for Palestinian markets that transit through Israeli ports, and then transfers the money to the PA.
The $138 million will likely be deducted incrementally over a 12-month period.
The PA has already facing a cut of more than $500 million in annual aid by Trump's administration, mostly to the UN agency for Palestinian refugees.
ba4011709a000c1afa3076954e332ef8:
Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas has rejected all tax revenue payments transferred to the PA by Israel.
Israel has withheld $138 million of the tax revenue payments over Ramallah’s payouts to Palestinian attackers and their families.
Israel currently collects and transfers $222 million to the PA every month.
Israel’s security cabinet approved withholding $138 million from a year’s worth of taxes that Israel is slated to collect on the PA’s behalf.
Abbas said that the PA will not receive any of the tax funds and will complain to international institutions.
A high-ranking Palestinian official said that the Palestinians cannot stop its payments to security prisoners or the families of slain attackers, calling such a move “political suicide”.
Palestinian officials have condemned Israel for moving to withhold the half billion shekels, arguing it amounts to “piracy” of Palestinian funds.
Israeli officials have defended the security cabinet’s decision, arguing that the PA’s payments incentivize violence and terrorism.
Abbas’s rejection of all tax revenues could mean a PA forfeiture of hundreds of millions of shekels each month – several billion a year, and perhaps as much as a third of the PA’s total budget.
Polls have found that the overwhelming majority of Palestinians oppose the PA suspending its payments to security prisoners, including terrorists who have killed Israeli civilians.
1ad7043cfa82d67ad4b871291ada7a83:
Palestinian Authority (PA) will no longer accept tax revenues collected by Israel due to Israel's decision to trim the sum over the PA’s financial support of militants’ families.
Israel collects about 700 million shekels ($193 million) in Palestinian taxes and transfers around 600 million shekels of that to the Palestinian Authority after deducting payments for electricity, water, sewage and medical treatment services.
Israel said it would freeze about 5 percent of that against stipends the Palestinian Authority pays to families of Palestinians killed or jailed by Israel.
PA will continue to pay out these stipends rather than accept a partial transfer of the tax revenues from Israel.
Israel and the United States say the stipend policy fans Palestinian violence while the Palestinians see the slain and jailed Palestinians as heroes of a national struggle.
The United States last year passed legislation to sharply reduce aid to the Palestinian Authority unless it stopped the pay-outs.
Last month the Palestinians declined some $60 million in U.S. annual funding for their security forces, worried about exposure to lawsuits under new U.S. anti-terror laws.
Washington has further slashed hundreds of millions of dollars to humanitarian organizations and U.N. agencies which aid the Palestinians as it seeks to pressure Abbas to enter peace negotiations with Israel.

Israeli troops shot and killed a Palestinian man near the perimeter fence with Israel early Saturday, hours before a planned mass rally to mark the annual Palestinian Land Day and the one-year anniversary of the start of weekly March of Return border protests.
The fatal shooting raised tensions at a time when Egyptian mediators, shuttling between Israel and Gaza’s Hamas rulers, are trying to broker a cease-fire deal that reportedly also includes proposed arrangements for preventing violence during Saturday’s protest.
Mohammed Saad, 21, was killed by Israeli army fire east of Gaza City near the perimeter fence, Gaza’s Hamas-run Health Ministry said, adding he was hit by shrapnel in the head.
Saad was a member of the so-called “night disturbance unit” that routinely burns tires, flashes laser lights and detonates explosives near the fence at night to distract soldiers and disturb residents of nearby Israeli communities.
Israel has been warning Palestinians against approaching or breaching the security fence during Saturday’s border protest.
The IDF’s Arabic-language spokesman on Saturday appealed directly to Gazans, saying benefits could be in store if they refrain from violence.
Demonstrations are expected to peak on Saturday afternoon, with tens of thousands potentially taking part.
Hamas, meanwhile, faces growing unrest in Gaza, as a result of worsening humanitarian conditions.
Egypt has repeatedly tried to broker a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas, stepping up efforts in recent days after a Gaza rocket struck a house in central Israel earlier this week, injuring seven Israelis and threatening renewed escalation.
On Saturday morning, Israeli troops arrested two Palestinian minors armed with knives attempting to breach the Gaza border fence.
db34a7488081075ef73d4fedefd56f70:
A Palestinian, Adham Amara, 17, was killed by Israeli fire during clashes and protests along the Gaza border on Saturday.
Tens of thousands of Palestinians were gathered along the Gaza-Israel border and dozens were wounded.
Another Palestinian was killed by Israeli fire in an overnight demonstration ahead of the main protest.
b3db22ca32dacc067f7bf305cd224623:
Israeli fire killed a Palestinian man near the Gaza border on Saturday.
The Israeli military said it had not heard of any such incident.
Tensions have mounted along the Israel-Gaza border this week ahead of the commemoration of the 'Great March of Return' border protests.
Fighting flared when a Palestinian rocket attack from Gaza wounded seven Israelis in a village north of Tel Aviv on Monday.
Israel launched a wave of air strikes and moved armour and reinforcements to the border in response to the Palestinian rocket attack.
The Israeli forces remained at the border area on Saturday and the military said it was expecting "violent riots" to take place and was prepared for escalation.
Tens of thousands of Palestinians were expected to attend the protests.
Egyptian mediators were working to avoid further bloodshed.
Leaders of Gazan armed groups Hamas and Islamic Jihad said that progress had been made in the truce talks.
About 200 Gazans have been killed by Israeli troops since the protests started.
An Israeli soldier was killed by a Palestinian sniper.
The demonstrations have turned into a standoff between Gazans hurling rocks and explosives and Israeli troops across the border.
Palestinians have also launched incendiary balloons and kites into Israel and breached the Israeli frontier fence.
Israel's use of lethal force has drawn censure from the United Nations and rights groups.
U.N. investigators said last week that Israeli forces may be guilty of war crimes for using excessive force.
Israel says it has no choice but to use deadly force at the protests to prevent militants from breaching the border fence and attacking civilian communities in the area.
The protesters are calling for the lifting of a security blockade imposed by Israel and Egypt, and for Palestinians to have the right to return to land from which their families fled or were forced to flee during Israel's founding in 1948.
More than 2 million Palestinians are packed into the narrow coastal enclave where poverty and unemployment rates are high.
The Isla mist Hamas group rules the territory and has fought three wars with Israel in the past decade.
The blockade is cited by humanitarian agencies as a key reason for impoverishment in Gaza.
Israel seized Gaza in a 1967 war and pulled out its troops in 2005.
The security blockade, Israel says, is necessary in order to stop weapons from reaching Hamas and other armed groups which have fired thousands of rockets into Israel.
cdebfa4496f71cacc544dd8b340c0839:
Four Palestinians were killed and 316 wounded by Israeli army fire during demonstrations marking the Land Day in the Gaza Strip.
64 of the wounded Palestinians were wounded by live ammunition.
14 of the wounded Palestinians were in a critical condition.
Tens of thousands of Palestinians organized huge rallies close to Gaza-Israel buffer zone to mark the first anniversary of demonstrations against the decades-long Israeli occupation.
fb6221bba1ae0d8baa5ef73abdbbc52e:
Four Palestinian demonstrators have been killed and more than 300 injured in clashes with the Israeli army on the Gaza border since Friday night.
The violence erupted between demonstrators and Israeli soldiers stationed on the Israel-Gaza border, as tens of thousands demonstrated to mark the one-year anniversary of the Great March of Return protests.
The Israeli army accused participants of throwing rocks and setting tyres on fire, and hurling grenades and explosive devices at the border fence.
The Israeli army fired tear gas and live gunfire at the demonstrators to keep them from approaching the fence.
The Gazan Health Ministry said yesterday evening that at least 316 Palestinians had been injured, 64 of whom sustained gunshots wounds.
The Great March of Return protests call for the right of return of Palestinian refugees and their descendants to the territory of today's Israel, as well as for an end to the 12-year-long blockade imposed by Israel.
A general strike was held in the Gaza Strip and the Health Ministry and Interior Ministry declared a state of emergency.
According to the Gaza Health Ministry, 269 Palestinians have been killed and thousands injured in the protests since they started one year ago.
The anniversary coincides with Land Day, which commemorates the death of six Arab Israelis who were killed by Israeli forces during protests against the expropriation of land by Israel in 1976.
Lieutenant-Colonel Jonathan Conricus, an Israeli military spokesman, said the day had "lots of rioters but significantly less violence", adding that it showed Hamas was able to stop violence when it wanted to.
bca7716c1de9bd414f2a1158a0f246eb:
The Palestinian Health Ministry in the Gaza Strip reported that Israeli soldiers killed 266 Palestinians and injured 30398 others since the Great Return March processions started on March 30, 2018.
On Saturday, March 30, 2019, four Palestinians were killed and 316, including 86 children and 29 women, were injured by Israeli army fire.
Among the slain Palestinians are two journalists, identified as Yasser Mortaja and Ahmad Abu Hussein, in the Gaza Strip.
The latest information does not include dozens of Palestinians who were killed and injured by the Israeli army after crossing the perimeter fence and were never returned to the Gaza Strip.
Mohammad Jihad Sa’ad was killed, east of Gaza city, on Friday morning, before the processions started.
64 Palestinians were shot with live fire.
16 Palestinians were shot with rubber-coated steel bullets.
13 Palestinians suffered wounds from shrapnel to several parts of the body.
46 Palestinians suffered teargas inhalation.
94 Palestinians were injured from gas bombs’ shrapnel.

Seven journalists were injured by army fire.
dd35d76be4ac0f8a87e03ebaabc64c20:
A Palestinian man, Fares Hajres, 26, succumbed to wounds sustained during riots and protests at the Israel-Gaza border last Saturday.
Hajres was reportedly shot in the stomach by Israeli troops in the border area near Khan Yunis.
Hajres is the fifth Gazan said to die from wounds sustained in clashes at the border over the weekend.
Three of those killed were aged 17 and took part in the protests.
Another Gazan died on Saturday from wounds sustained in a border clash earlier that morning.
At least 300 were injured Saturday, three of whom suffered critical injuries.
Some rioters at the Saturday rallies threw grenades and explosives toward the security fence, while others lobbed rocks at Israeli troops and burned tires.
Hamas actively worked to keep protesters away from the security fence as part of apparent understandings with Israel.
The Israeli army said that while soldiers were forced to respond with “riot dispersal means” and live fire in accordance with Israel Defense Forces regulations at times, most Palestinians attending the anniversary protests remained at a distance from the border.

7707171689d3e67b731fb2e969f300a3: A 26-year-old Palestinian young man died on Tuesday from a gunshot wound to the abdomen sustained during a weekly protest on the border fence in the Gaza Strip last Saturday.

24ececddddf415fc0ac3dd05c300b0dd:

d2cc01734eac93a8f977f59c879c3033:
Israeli forces attacked Palestinians taking part in an anti-occupation protest along the edge of the besieged Gaza Strip, injuring 83 people.

A United Nations (UN) fact-finding mission found that Israeli forces committed rights violations during their crackdown against the Palestinian protesters in Gaza that may amount to war crimes.

05fdd2db82f137feaf967ef03065344c:
Two weeks ago, Palestinians rioted on the Temple Mount, breaking into an area adjacent to Sha’ar HaRachamim (Gate of Mercy, also known as the Golden Gate) in the Temple Mount compound.
The site was locked 16 years ago by court order after it was used as a meeting place for a Hamas-affiliated organization.
The Israeli police have allowed Muslim prayers at the site and have thus far avoided confrontations.
The Waqf (Muslim authority) requested permission from the Israeli police to bring in materials to convert the site to a Mosque and their request has not been rejected.
The police issued restraining orders against Waqf guards and Palestinian activists, including the Waqf’s head, Sheikh Abdel-Azeem Salhab, to prevent them from reaching the site.
An Israeli delegation traveled to Jordan last Thursday to discuss a solution with the government.
Israel wants the renovations at Sha’ar HaRachamim to take place alongside archaeologists from Israel’s Antiquities Authority but the Jordanians rejected this condition.
Israeli media reported that Jordan offered that the site be closed for long-term renovations.
The Israeli delegation agreed to this plan but insisted it must first be closed without renovations taking place, as a statement of Israeli authority.
Arutz Sheva, a Hebrew language news site, reported on Friday that a compromise had been reached between Israel and Jordan over the situation at the Sha’ar HaRachamim.
Arutz Sheva cited the London-based Asharq al-Awsat newspaper which claimed that the Israeli government agreed to allow the Waqf (Muslim authority) to bring in building materials in order to renovate the site and convert it into a mosque.
Arutz Sheva reported on Sunday that negotiations between the Israeli police, the Israeli National Security Council, and the Waqf had agreed that leaks in the roof would be renovated by the Waqf in cooperation with Israeli police and archaeologists.
After the renovation, the Waqf will be allowed to use the building for classes, twice a month.
In the wake of the failed talks, King Abdullah of Jordan traveled to the U.S. to meet with members of Congress.
e9bc5cce7b0766494d39cd1c9a90ecae:
Foreign Minister Ayman Safadi and Saeb Erekat, secretary general of the Palestinian Liberation Organisation's (PLO) executive committee, stressed the unified Jordanian-Palestinian stance on the Palestinian cause.
The unified Jordanian-Palestinian stance emphasizes that the only road to comprehensive peace is one that meets all the Palestinians’ legitimate rights, foremost of which is the right of the Palestinian people to freedom and an independent Palestinian state along the June 4, 1967 borders, with East Jerusalem as its capital.
Safadi and Erekat reaffirmed the cohesion of Jordanian-Palestinian efforts that seek to protect Jerusalem’s Muslim and Christian holy sites.
Safadi stressed Jordan’s utter rejection of the Israeli court’s decision to close Bab Al Rahmah and any steps taken in attempt to change its legal and historical status.
Safadi added that Jordan does not recognize the legitimacy of the Israeli court in East Jerusalem, pointing out that the Jerusalem Awqaf Department is the only authority with jurisdiction to manage Al Haram Al Sharif in accordance with international law.
Erekat expressed his appreciation, on behalf of the Palestinian state, for the “King’s efforts, as the patron of Christian and Muslim holy sites, in protecting the Arab-Islamic identity of Jerusalem’s holy sites, and his efforts to protect Bab Al Rahmah to preserve its historical status”.
Safadi and Erekat agreed to continue coordination and negotiation in fulfillment of the King and Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas’ directives.
Safadi and Erekat highlighted the importance of maintaining cooperation between Jordan and Palestine in pursuit of a peace that restores the rights of the Palestinians to freedom and statehood, in accordance with a two-state solution, international legislation and the Arab Peace Initiative.
1744e15258d7c27c47ee5bb539d30629:
King Abdullah II of Jordan stated that his position on Jerusalem is "unwavering" and all the Jordanian people are with him.
Jordan has a historical duty towards Jerusalem as well as the Islamic and Christian holy sites there.
King Abdullah II said "To me, Jerusalem is a red line, and all my people are with me."
King Abdullah II said "No one can pressure Jordan on this matter, and the answer will be no. All Jordanians stand with me on Jerusalem. At the end of the day, Arabs and Muslims will stand with us as well."
King Abdullah II said "to anyone who speaks about an alternative homeland, the answer is no."
ff15d0c8b598d3f7909efc0d4e048e55:
Jordan’s King Abdullah II has vowed to keep protecting Islamic and Christian holy sites in Jerusalem, calling it a “red line” for his country.
Abdullah said he’s under pressure to alter his country’s historic role as custodian of the Jerusalem holy sites, but that he won’t change his position.
The Waqf, a Jordanian-appointed council oversees Muslim holy sites in Jerusalem.
Saudi Arabia is already the custodian of the two holiest sites in Mecca and Medina, both within its territory.
Middle East pundits have in the past suggested that Saudi Arabia is interested in taking over responsibility for the Temple Mount and the mosques within its compound.
After Israel’s general election in April, the Trump administration is poised to reveal its “deal of the century” peace plan for resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
f82cface28d0decb481accc4930fdf83:
Jordanian Foreign Minister Ayman Al-Safadi said Jordan "rejects any change in the status quo of Jerusalem."
Al-Safadi said the two-state solution is the best solution to end the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, with East Jerusalem as the capital of the Palestinian state.
Al-Safadi and Hungarian counterpart Peter Szijjarto discussed the Syria issue and stressed the importance of a political solution.
Hungary's embassy to Israel is located in Tel Aviv and there are no plans to relocate it to Jerusalem.
Hungary opened a foreign trade representation office in Jerusalem, which the Palestinian Foreign Ministry described as an "aggression against all Palestinians, Arabs and Muslims around the world".
6be2ff139c707e3dcf5d8cc6cf6ec0df:
Foreign Minister Ayman Safadi and Secretary General of the Palestinian Liberation Organisation's Executive Committee Saeb Erekat met to discuss the Palestinian-Israeli conflict and Israeli provocations in East Jerusalem.
Both sides agreed on the right of the Palestinian people to freedom and an independent Palestinian state along the June 4, 1967 borders, with East Jerusalem as its capital.
The Palestinian side recognized and supported the Hashemite Custodianship over the Islamic and Christian holy places in East Jerusalem.
The Jerusalem Awqaf Department has the sole authority to determine the status of any part or entrance belonging to these Islamic sites.
The unity of ranks between Jordan and the Palestinian Authority (PA) reinforces Jordan's role as the protector of the holy places in East Jerusalem.
There is a pressing need for an Arab and or an Islamic summit on East Jerusalem to discuss the latest developments.
f24f2966cee0326b83fa1392890fe759:
King Abdullah of Jordan declared Zarqa as a major metropolitan urban city in Jordan that is home to about 50 per cent of the country’s industries and businesses.
King Abdullah chose Zarqa to make momentous declarations, especially on East Jerusalem and its Muslim and Christian holy places.
King Abdullah said that East Jerusalem is a red line, that no side can cross with impunity.
King Abdullah said that no one can pressure Jordan on the matter of East Jerusalem, and the answer will be no.
King Abdullah said that all Jordanians stand with him on Jerusalem, and at the end of the day, Arabs and Muslims will stand with Jordan as well.
King Abdullah said that the Jordanian custodianship over the holy sites in East Jerusalem is a red line that he will uphold at all costs.
King Abdullah said that he remains sanguine about the future, despite all the odds that the country faces, which undermine its stability and progress.
King Abdullah said that some countries were actually applying pressure on his steadfastness on East Jerusalem, but he reiterated that he will not waver.
King Abdullah said that Jordan’s stance on East Jerusalem and its holy places is a matter of principle and not a subject for negotiation.
King Abdullah said that any talk about an “alternative homeland” for Palestinians in Jordan is rejected, noting that “to anyone who speaks about an alternative homeland, the answer is no”.
King Abdullah said that Jordan is Jordan and Palestine is Palestine.
King Abdullah said that only when the state of Palestine is created on Palestinian soil in the West Bank, with East Jerusalem as it capital, would Jordan consider some form of unification or another.
b51c48fe16ab89dbcbd0352c64786215:
King Abdullah and Crown Prince Hussein attended the 51st anniversary of the Karameh Battle at the Unknown Soldier Monument in the Jordan Valley.
On March 21, 1968, Jordanian soldiers repelled an Israeli attack on Karameh town in the Jordan Valley.
86 Jordanian soldiers died and 108 were wounded in the battle.
250 Israeli soldiers were killed and 450 were wounded in the battle.
King Abdullah reviewed the guard of honour, laid wreaths at the monument and recited verses from the Koran at the site.
JAF Mufti Brig. Gen. Majed Darawsheh paid tribute to the fallen soldiers of the Arab Army.
1651f84bfa85cf84fd2a05dbbbdfd206:
American activity in the region is increasing, particularly towards regional settlement, as Secretary of State Mike Pompeo visits Israel this week.
Palestinian Authority leader Mahmoud Abbas has asked Mohammad Shtayyeh to form a new government as prime minister, potentially representing a new era in Palestinian leadership.
Jordan's King Abdullah recently travelled to Washington to meet with President Donald Trump's Middle East team, as Jordan's problems are not limited to economics and require immediate intervention.

Jordan needs pragmatic positions on the issue of Jerusalem, threats to Jordanian merchants with ties with Damascus and its relations with Saudi Arabia.

American activity in the region is increasing, particularly towards regional settlement, as Secretary of State Mike Pompeo visits Israel this week.

King Abdullah of Jordan warned that Jerusalem is a red line and that the Jordanian people stand behind him on this issue.

f82037830c293c14c9a35e5d3e2ab257:
Jordan is the custodian of Jerusalem's waqf, including the Haram Al Sharif, and provides refuge, education, and travel documents for many stateless Palestinians in the city.
Jordan's physical presence in Jerusalem is limited, and many Jerusalemites are frustrated with Jordan's perceived inaction in supporting Palestinian representation and ending the Israeli occupation.
Jordan's role in Jerusalem is tied to its relationship with Israel, as it depends on Israel economically and politically but also serves as a crucial intermediary during tensions.
Jordan employs around 1,000 guards and staff at the Haram Al Sharif and negotiates with Israel when the status quo is challenged.
Jordan created a new Jordanian Islamic Waqf Endowment Council in February 2023, including Palestinian members, and has attempted to enter the Bab Al Rahmeh prayer hall, which Israel made off-limits to Muslims in 2003.
Jordan's Madrasati Palestine initiative has renovated schools and provided educational support in Jerusalem.
Historically, Jordan has competed with the PLO and PA for representation of Palestinians, but renounced its claim in 1988.
Jordan and Palestine signed an agreement in 2013 affirming Jordan's role as custodian of Muslim holy sites in Jerusalem, while Palestine retains sovereignty.
Some Jerusalemite Palestinians view Jordan's management of Al Aqsa as a form of control, leading to tensions.
Jordan's role in Jerusalem is expected to deepen amid political uncertainty, but some argue that it has not been sufficiently robust in supporting Palestinian interests.

The Hashemite role in protecting the Islamic and Christian holy places has already won international acclaim, recognition and appreciation.
Jordan's Jerusalem Awqaf Department has also won recognition as the sole entity that has authority and mandate to administer Al Aqsa Mosque.

The 14th ordinary summit of the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) will be held in Makkah, Saudi Arabia, on Friday with the theme "Hand in Hand toward the Future."
The summit will be chaired by Saudi Arabia's King Salman and will address issues affecting the Muslim world, including the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, rising anti-Muslim prejudice, and violent extremism.
The summit will also address the consequences of the US decision to move its embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, the suffering of Syrian civilians due to an ongoing military assault in Idlib province, and the destabilizing activities of Iran and its proxy forces in the Middle East.
The summit will coincide with two emergency meetings — the Arab League and Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) summits — called by King Salman amid escalating tensions between Iran on one side and the US and its Gulf allies on the other.
The summit will also address the attacks on four commercial vessels near the UAE's Fujairah port earlier this month, which have raised serious questions about maritime security in the Gulf.
Saudi Foreign Minister Ibrahim Al-Assaf said that "Tehran's support for Houthi rebels in Yemen is proof of Iranian interference in other nations' affairs, and this is something that ... Islamic countries should reject."
Al-Assaf also called for a UN-backed political solution in Syria and emphasized that the Palestinian issue is a paramount Saudi concern.
OIC Secretary-General Yousef Al-Othaimeen expressed his gratitude to King Salman and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman for Saudi Arabia's hosting of the summit.
An anti-extremism document was signed by 1,200 figures from the Muslim world during a gathering in Makkah in the lead up to the Islamic Summit.
The document condemns attacks on places of worship, calling them criminal acts that require a strong legislative and security response.
The document urges non-interference in the affairs of other states and singles out for criticism dissemination of sectarian ideas.
The document recognizes the importance of women's empowerment, rejects their marginalization, and opposes the denial of opportunities for them in various fields.
The document says it is everyone's duty to fight terrorism, injustice, oppression and human rights violations.
International-relations analyst Salem Al-Yami said that the three conferences in Makkah are taking place at a sensitive and critical moment for the Middle East.
Al-Yami said that the objective of the summits is to clarify the picture and devise ways to confront the challenges.
The OIC is the second-largest inter-governmental institution after the UN, with 57 member states from four continents.
9ca301bdb6822185a14b4f9ad977f780:
Saudi Foreign Minister Dr. Ibrahim bin Abdulaziz Al-Assaf has affirmed the success of Gulf and Arab summits in garnering support for Saudi and UAE position against the actions carried out by the Iranian-backed Houthi militia.
The Iranian-backed Houthi militia were behind the attacks on two oil pumping stations in the Kingdom by using armed drones, and also sabotaged commercial vessels near the UAE's territorial waters.
The GCC countries have expressed their desire for peace and cooperation with Iran, but "Iran must stop supporting terrorist acts in our countries and be a cooperative neighbour".
The focus of these meetings was on the terrorist attacks on vessels near the UAE's territorial waters and the drone attacks on two pumping stations in Afif and Dawadmi governorates in Saudi Arabia.
The Iranian-backed terrorist Houthi militia has so far carried out 225 missiles and 155 drones attacks against the Kingdom.
These attacks have gone beyond the goals of the previous attacks.
Qatar had participated in previous summits.
The Arab quartet's position is to find a solution to the causes of the crisis between these countries and Qatar, and there will be a solution "if Qatar returns to the right path".
The concern from Iran is not only about its support for the Houthi militia and other terrorist groups, including the terrorist Hezbollah in Lebanon, but also their interference in the internal affairs of other countries such as Bahrain.
Iran's development of ballistic missiles and nuclear capabilities poses a direct threat to the Gulf states.
Iran's transgressions and support for the groups have exceeded Arab and neighbouring countries to Latin America and America "when they tried to assassinate the Saudi ambassador in Washington".
The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia's approach is clear, as it has repeatedly called for constructive and peaceful relations with Iran.
afc771be60d1250e7856109aaa5b4611:
The 14th Islamic Summit was held in Makkah on Friday evening under the chairmanship of King Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud.
The OIC Member States denounced terrorism, extremism and fanaticism in all their forms and manifestations.
The OIC Member States denounced the terrorist attacks against Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.
The OIC Member States stressed the need to work earnestly in order to counter the political, economic and cultural challenges facing OIC member States.
The OIC Member States underscored the necessity of working toward preserving security and stability and opening venues of investment and sustainable development.
The OIC Member States stressed the OIC Member States' endeavors to end Israeli occupation of Arab and Palestinian territories occupied since 1967.
The OIC Member States emphasized the importance of closing ranks to stand up against terrorist organizations and enacting deterrent laws and controls to counter the scourge of terrorism.
d2abbc72f5090525938ea5bcaaa035e4:
The 14th Summit of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) started in Makkah, Saudi Arabia, under the chairmanship of King Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud.
The UAE delegation to the Islamic Summit is led by H.H. Sheikh Saud bin Saqr Al Qasimi, Supreme Council Member and Ruler of Ras Al Khaimah.
The summit focuses on the Palestinian cause and developments in the Arab, African and Asian regions.
King Salman opened the summit by affirming that the Palestinian cause remains the top priority of the OIC's work.
King Salman condemned the recent sabotage attacks against commercial vessels in the UAE's regional waters and the bomb-laden drone strikes on Saudi pumping stations.
The OIC Secretary General Dr. Yousef bin Ahmad Al-Othaimeen said that terrorism can never be associated with any religion.
8909824981b9995313acd4c6f3eb615b:
Qatar rejected the outcome of the Mecca talks on mounting regional tensions with Iran as it had not been properly consulted.
Saudi Arabia hosted three summits in Mecca over the weekend critical of Iran after King Salman warned that "terrorist" attacks in the Gulf region could imperil global energy supplies.
Qatar has reservations on the Arab and Gulf summits because some of their terms are contrary to Doha's foreign policy.
Tehran has strongly denied involvement in recent attacks on oil infrastructure and regional shipping.
Qatar is the subject of a two-year Saudi-led economic embargo including bans on direct air, land and sea travel between the boycotting nations and Qatar, as well sanctions.
Doha has looked to Tehran to ease its economic isolation, sourcing key imports from Iran and re-routing many flights by its flag carrier Qatar Airways over the Islamic republic.
Qatar hoped the Mecca summits would lay the groundwork for dialogue to reduce tensions with Iran.
The Mecca summit ignored the important issues in the region, such as the Palestine issue and the war in Libya and Yemen.
8b4c029b6c19175e1770d68d49966108:
The 14th Islamic Summit, hosted by the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, has commenced in Mecca.
The summit aims to develop a unified stance on events in the Islamic world, including the Palestinian cause, Islamophobia, countering extremism and terrorism, and the situation of Muslims around the world.
Saudi King Salman bin Abdulaziz opened the session by saying that the Palestinian cause remains the top priority of the OIC’s work.
King Salman also spoke on the recent attacks on the Arabian Gulf, saying that the assaults were “not only target the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and the UAE, but also the maritime traffic, the maritime movement, and the oil supply globally.”
OIC Secretary-General Yousef Al-Othaimeen reiterated Saudi King Salman’s statement regarding the Palestinian cause, adding that the Islamic organization “insists on the historic rights of Palestinians and on the two-state solution.”
Al-Othaimeen also said that terrorism is not associated with any religion, citing the recent Christchurch mosque shootings in New Zealand.
Analysts expect the Islamic summit to support the policies in place regarding Iran.
f605ae4b358607f3ac19f847a67a08af:
The diplomatic crisis between the Arab Quartet (Saudi Arabia, UAE, Bahrain, and Egypt) and Qatar marks its second anniversary on June 5.
The crisis began due to Qatar's support for Hamas, the Muslim Brotherhood, Iran, and Turkey.
Qatar has not changed its policies despite the crisis, continuing to support Hamas, the Muslim Brotherhood, and Al Jazeera's biased coverage.
Qatar has also maintained close relations with Iran and Turkey, welcoming Turkish troops and receiving Iranian support.
The UAE has filed a complaint against Qatar at the World Trade Organization (WTO) for banning Emirati products.
Saudi Arabia invited Qatar to attend two summits in Mecca to discuss "aggression" in the Gulf.
Kuwaiti journalist Fouad Hashem predicts the crisis will last for another 2-3 years, with Qatar expanding its influence in the Arab World.
Qatar hosted Michael Klein, president of the Zionist Organization of America (ZOA), in December 2017, seeking Zionist support.
c89817873f85de314dc44591fc32ce6c:
Saudi Arabia's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Adel al-Jubeir, criticized Qatar for reversing its position on Mecca summits' communiques.
Al-Jubeir said that countries should declare their positions during meetings and conferences, not afterward.
Qatar has reservations about two communiques rejecting Iran's interference in the region's affairs.
The communique of the Arab emergency summit in Mecca stressed the centrality of the Palestinian cause and the establishment of a Palestinian State on the 1967 borders with Jerusalem as its capital.
Qatar's Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al-Thani said that the communiques reflected Washington's policies on Iran, not a policy that took into consideration Iran as a neighbor.

Qatar has reservations on the Arab and Gulf summits because some of their terms are contrary to Doha's foreign policy.
Tehran has strongly denied involvement in recent attacks on oil infrastructure and regional shipping.
Qatar is the subject of a two-year Saudi-led economic embargo including bans on direct air, land and sea travel between the boycotting nations and Qatar, as well sanctions.
The Gulf summit statement talked about a unified Gulf, but where is it amid the continuation of Qatar's blockade?
The summits "adopted Washington's policy towards Iran and not one that takes the neighbourhood into consideration".
Doha has looked to Tehran to ease its economic isolation, sourcing key imports from Iran and re-routing many flights by its flag carrier Qatar Airways over the Islamic republic.
The Makkah summit ignored the important issues in the region, such as the Palestine issue and the war in Libya and Yemen.
25848eab6aa41bba0b98e14a490a9fdc:
Saudi Arabia's King Salman and Qatar's Prime Minister Sheikh Abdullah bin Nasser Al-Thani met in Makkah on Thursday, the highest level encounter between the neighbors since the start of the two-year economic boycott of Qatar.
The meeting was closely watched, but no bowing or cheek-kissing was observed between the two leaders, indicating the persistence of tensions.
Diplomats believe the embargo is unlikely to ease following the frosty encounter.
Qatar's Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani questioned the Gulf summit statement's call for a unified Gulf, highlighting the ongoing blockade of Qatar.
Saudi Arabia's minister of state for foreign affairs Adel al-Jubeir criticized Qatar for backtracking after the meetings and accused it of distorting facts.
A European diplomatic source believes Qatar's sending of its prime minister instead of the foreign minister to the talks is a novelty.
Andreas Krieg, an assistant professor at King's College London, views the king's invitation to the talks without "strings attached" as a positive sign.
The Makkah meetings followed hawkish US National Security Adviser John Bolton's accusation that Iran was behind the sabotage of four ships, including two Saudi oil tankers, off the coast of the United Arab Emirates.
Qatar has sourced key imports from Iran and rerouted many flights over the Islamic republic to ease its economic isolation.
The Saudi-led bloc initially set out a 13-point list of demands, including the closure of Qatar's Al Jazeera broadcaster and curbing its relations with Iran.
Ordinary people have borne the brunt of the restrictions, with families separated and students unable to attend universities in neighboring countries.
f0c46384c40a1df4d2f31d30deebdfbb:
US President Donald Trump will host Qatar's Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al-Thani at the White House on July 9.
The two leaders will discuss "economic and security ties" and counterterrorism issues.
Qatar has maintained cordial relations with Tehran even as other Arab states have cooperated with Trump's "maximum pressure" campaign against Iran.
Saudi Arabia and its allies have boycotted Qatar for two years due to Qatar's insistence on maintaining its own approach to regional relations and links with Iran and terrorist organizations.
Qatar will take part in the June 25-26 Bahrain conference on the Trump administration's Israeli-Palestinian peace initiative.

UAE Minister of State for Foreign Affairs Anwar Gargash criticized Qatari media for "fabrication" of news on him being in Sudan's Khartoum.
